column4: got a question, i have a heavily moddified 6.06 installation (mysql, cacti, php, apache, smokeping, munin, monit) if i upgrade to 6.10 will my system survive? i of course will make a backup first. any thoughts?
Are all those things in the repositories? (I know most of them are)
yes, but the onces i have installed are the latest versions, the ones on the repositories are always out of date
ah, so they're not packages.  Then you may have issues, depending on how you manually installed them.
Edits of the config isn't the issue, it's the fact that you've installed from source on those packages.
that's correct.  You must go through Edgy
Ubuntu software will always be a little out of date version number wise, that's the nature of time based releases.

understood, but those timed released version were to old and had to many bugs and security holes, so i decied to manually compile and edit them, in hindsight that prolly will have made for a messy system upgrade
Security holes?  Doubt that.  They keep them pretty well patched.
You might be interested in some other linux distro.  One that does more of a rolling current release.
take cacti, still has a old version of it that has serious security holes that allow for remote code execution
cacti is in universe, you should contact the package maintainer.
which holes?  are you sure hey're still there and not patched?
right, the new version won't be backported, but all the patches will.  http://changelogs.ubuntu.com/changelogs/pool/universe/c/cacti/cacti_0.8.6h-1ubuntu3/changelog
but really, stuff in universe is maintained by individuals, not a security team.  You should contact the maintainer about getting the patches integrated.
right, well, if you did the former, you wouldn't have to worry about upgrade issues either.
this is a work server or anything, just my linux box at home i use to monitor my lap and personal network and all the other computers around the house
